text.p: Suppose [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] are vector spaces with the same (finite) dimension [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline].
If [mathjaxinline]T: V\rightarrow W[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation which is onto, what is the rank of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?
Therefore, what is the nullity of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?
Therefore, we can conclude that [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] must be what? (Answer yourself.)

font.p: Since [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is onto, the dimension of the image is equal to the dimension of the codomain. Thus, the dimension of the image, and the rank of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline], is [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline]. Since the dimension of the domain is [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline], by the rank nullity theorem, the nullity of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is [mathjaxinline]n-n=0[/mathjaxinline].
Since the nullity is zero, the kernel of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is trivial. Thus [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is into.
